utterances: The frustration could be so high with the Red Cross after what happened, after Katrina, that I wouldn't be surprised if they started thinking about some different approaches to how the disaster plan gets implemented.

Ten races to go in the NASCAR season.
More than 40 cars are competing, but only the top 10 drivers are in the chase for the championship.
Tomorrow's race is in New Hampshire.
NPR's Noah Adams went to an event there earlier in the season.
He was curious about the staying power of the number 3.
The number that belonged to seven-time champion and legend, Dale Earnhardt.
He died on a racetrack four and a half years ago.
The 3 is still Dale Earnhardt's number.
You won't see it on another car.
It is a simple design, white with a red outline.
(Soundbite of NASCAR audience noise)
The number is slanted as if it were in motion.
(Soundbite of NASCAR race in progress)
A NASCAR race is a bunch of sound, usually a ton of heat and humidity and a lot of people who respect Dale Earnhardt.
In July, at the New Hampshire International Speedway, I parked to a minivan that had Canadian plates.
John Wooden(ph) is from Nova Scotia.
Earnhardt is still big in Canada.
Everybody talks about him and I still watch old races on Speed Channel and whatnot when he was driving just to watch him drive.
One hundred-one thousand people showed up on race day at Loudon, New Hampshire and, imagine, 8,000 RVs.
I walked up the hill to the camping area where they had established themselves, often returning to the same spot every year.
Some even had the morning newspaper waiting outside their door.
It's easy to get an invitation for sausage and eggs.
Who's a Dale Sr. fan?
Unidentified Woman #1: We all are.
Are you?
Unidentified Woman #2: No, I'm not.
Unidentified Woman #3: We're not into racing.
We're just...
Unidentified Woman #2: We just come with the guys.
Oh, OK.
Tell me about Dale Sr.
Unidentified Woman #1: He affected everybody.
He's a regular guy like us.
He's, you know...
And it was easy to find the number 3.
Sometimes it would be high on a flagpole.
That's always the case for the Grant family of Lewiston, Maine.
Standard family joke is when we called somebody to come and meet us at the racetrack is that we'll be the one flying the Earnhardt flag.
Of course, that's a joke because there's probably 4,000 of them.
At the campground I also saw a black circle decal on a window in memory of 3, 1951-2001, and a New Hampshire license plate which read: DALE3N8.
This means Dale Sr. and Dale Earnhardt Jr. who is a bright hope for NASCAR.
He drives the red Budweiser number 8 car and people will say about the symbolism that the 8 completes the 3.
(Soundbite of a small motor)
Then I found a New York plate and it was cryptic: MZTH3.
Randy Braman explains.
It says, `Miss the 3.
MZ the 3, Dale Earnhardt.
MZTH3?
Yep.
We miss him.
Miss the 3.
(Soundbite of car motors and small electric tool sounds)
Dale Earnhardt won 76 NASCAR races.
They called him the Intimidator.
And he liked that and took out a trademark on the word.
A driver would see Earnhardt in the rear-view mirror.
He had a scary look and sometimes they'd just let him go on past.
The fans have their favorite Earnhardt `miracle tales.
For Diane Gillespie(ph), of Massachusetts, it was a come-from-18-places-back victory at Talladega with only a few laps left.
Five laps, right, honey?
Mr. BOB WADDINGTON(ph) (Earnhardt Fan): Yeah.
Five, yeah.

I was sitting there.
I thought he'd never do it.

Kingston says there was a protest at the proposed Scion site and an online opposition campaign.
In the end, the project has not got off the ground.
The Trump Organization did not respond to inquiries about this story.
It's hard to draw a straight line between the business setbacks and the president's policies or comments.
Trump hasn't released his tax returns, but his mandatory financial disclosure reports offer a snapshot into his business.
Some of his businesses around the world are not doing particularly well.
But the ones he frequents as president are doing better than ever.
Austin Evans (ph) is with the accountability organization American Oversight.
He says golf courses where Trump plays regularly at New Jersey and in Virginia are doing well.
And you see that at The Trump International Hotel, which got to raise rates in 2017 and went from predicting that it would run a loss to turning a profit.
And you also see increased profits at Mar-a-Lago, which the president has rebranded as the winter White House.
Trump's hotel in D.C.
is a few blocks from the White House.
Bloomberg's O'Brien says the president is known to dine there.
O'BRIEN: We know that lobbyists, diplomats and members of the Trump administration frequent that hotel not simply because it has comfortable rooms and good food.
They are seeking access.
And Trump and his family profit from the fact that he's president, and they have a hotel in town, and they're making good money off that.
And those profits, O'Brien says, may make up for the ones lost at his other properties.
Jackie Northam, NPR News.

The Jena Six case has hit Capitol Hill.
The House Judiciary Committee held hearings yesterday about events in a small Louisiana town that sparked a national debate over race and justice.
White students accused of hanging nooses on a high school campus were suspended from school but not formally prosecuted.
Six black teens accused of subsequently beating a white classmate faced charges as high as attempted murder.
Democratic legislatures - legislators said the federal officials sort of intervened in what they saw as a race-based prosecution.
Here's Congresswoman Sheila Jackson-Lee addressing U.S.
Attorney Donald Washington.
Why didn't you intervene?
These broken lies could have been prevented if you had taken the symbolic responsibility that you have being the first African-American appointed to the Western district.
I don't know what else to say.
I am outrage.
And that's why my voice is going up like this, literally, outraged.
(Soundbite of applause)
Washington fought back.
